intro: Linnaea borealis f. confluens, commonly known as the twinflower, is a rare and unique variant of the twinflower plant native to northern regions of the Northern Hemisphere. This form is characterized by its distinctive two-flowered inflorescence, where two small, pinkish-white flowers are borne on a single stem. The plant is a low-growing evergreen shrub with opposite, oval-shaped leaves that are often covered in a dense layer of fine, white hairs. It thrives in cool, moist environments such as boreal forests and rocky slopes, where it forms dense mats. Its botanical features make it an important indicator species for certain ecological conditions in its native habitat.
